channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War : Deadly Russian Strike Hits Eastern Ukraine as Blinken Visits Kyiv
item.description: A Russian missile strike killed at least 16 people in the town of Kostyantynivka, Ukraine’s president said. The attack came hours after the U.S. secretary of state arrived in Kyiv for an unannounced visit.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed home in Yatskivka village on the road from Izium to Lyman, in Ukraine on Tuesday.

item.title: Slovakia Election Could Shift Sentiment in a Fierce Ukraine Ally
item.description: The vote in Slovakia this month will be a test of European unity on Ukraine, and of Russia’s efforts to undermine it. The front-runner wants to halt arms shipments to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Robert Fico, a former prime minister of Slovakia and the front-runner in the election, opposes helping Ukraine. The vote will show whether that stance could take hold in Europe’s political mainstream.

item.title: China’s Economic Pain Is a Test of Xi’s Fixation With Control
item.description: The slowdown is posing perhaps the most sustained challenge to President Xi Jinping’s agenda in over a decade in power. He now faces a tangle of difficult choices.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping’s strategy of ruling of China through highly centralized control is under pressure.

item.title: At Least 22 Dead After Flooding From Cyclone in Brazil
item.description: More than 3,000 people were displaced as towns flooded in the states of Rio Grande do Sul and Santa Catarina. Rains were forecast to continue.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Mateus Bruxel/Agencia RBS, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Flooding in Muçum, Rio Grande do Sul State, Brazil, on Tuesday.

item.title: G20 Summit in India: Why It Still Matters and What to Expect
item.description: Summits like the one in India this weekend have produced many ambitious statements — and, often, disappointing results. Critics say an upgrade is needed.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: President Biden, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany during the Group of 20 summit in Indonesia last year.

item.title: Mass Hunger Strike in Bahrain Prison Sets Off Rare Protests
item.description: In a kingdom that crushed an Arab Spring uprising more than a decade ago, prisoners are now on hunger strike to demand better conditions, fueling protests in support of their cause.
item.dc:creator: Nazeeha Saeed and Vivian Nereim
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: A satellite photo taken in July of the Jau prison in Bahrain, where prisoners are almost a month into a hunger strike.

item.title: UK Air Traffic Control Chaos Was a ‘1 in 15 Million’ Problem
item.description: Air traffic computer systems shut down after receiving duplicate data, a report found, forcing plans to be processed manually.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Hundreds of flights in and out of Britain were delayed or canceled on Aug. 28 and 29 because of a technical failure.

item.title: Ex-Colombian Soldier Is Set to Plead Guilty in Killing of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti
item.description: A former Colombian Army captain who is accused of playing a leading role in the 2021 killing will change his plea to guilty, a sign that he may testify against his co-defendants.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural depicting the assassinated president of Haiti, Jovenel Moïse, near the entrance to his home in Pétionville.

item.title: Jorge Vilda, Coach of Spain’s Women’s Soccer Team, Is Fired
item.description: Players had accused the coach, Jorge Vilda, of outdated methods and controlling behavior. His boss, Luis Rubiales, is still embroiled in scandal over a nonconsensual kiss.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: Jorge Vilda, the head coach of the Spanish women’s soccer team, after the team’s victory in the World Cup final in Australia last month.

item.title: Record Rains Flood Greece, Turkey and Bulgaria, Killing at Least 7
item.description: The deluge caused extensive damage and a death in Greece, just as firefighters contained blazes there. Floods in Bulgaria and Turkey also led to six fatalities in total.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Rising water in Volos, Greece, on Tuesday. The mayor, Achilleas Beos, shouted at motorists in partly submerged cars, “Where are you going? This is insane! Go home!”

item.title: South Korean Teachers Rally for Protections From Harassing Parents
item.description: For months, tens of thousands of educators have protested nationwide against a rule they say keeps them from disciplining students for fear of being accused of child abuse.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: South Korean teachers at a rally in front of the National Assembly in Seoul on Monday.

item.title: Leaders of Canadian Trucker Protest Go on Trial
item.description: Two key organizers of the 2022 trucker protest argued that their efforts were a form of free speech, as prosecutors asserted that “this case is not about their political views.”
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers began to make arrests at the trucker protest in Ottawa in February 2022.

item.title: North Korea Finds New Leverage in the Ukraine War
item.description: Kim Jong-un is likely to seek missile and warhead technology in an expected visit to Russia, and he is already getting a public embrace he has long sought.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: North Korea leader Kim Jong-un with Russia’s President Vladimir V. Putin in Vladivostok, Russia, in 2019. Russia has long been a crucial ally for the isolated North Korea.

item.title: Vanuatu Prime Minister Is Ousted Amid Criticism of Being Pro-West
item.description: The prime minister of Vanuatu lost his job after he was criticized for veering too close to the West. He accuses his successor of being too cozy with China.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Christopher Cottrell
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: When President Emmanuel Macron of France, center left, visited Port Vila, Vanuatu’s capital, in July, he was welcomed by Ishmael Kalsakau, then the prime minister.

item.title: British Bees Face a Deadly Invasion
item.description: The number of sightings of Asian hornets, an invasive species that can wipe out bee colonies, has spiked this year, raising concerns among British beekeepers.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Axel Heimken/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Asian hornets were first detected in France in 2005 and have since spread to other European countries, as well as Britain.

item.title: How to Spot a Wildfire: Weighing Fire Lookouts and Technology
item.description: Officials say the future of wildfire detection is cameras. But in northwest Montana, solitary humans on mountaintops still do more than machines alone can offer.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Mark Felix
item.media:description: Leif Haugen with his morning coffee at the Thoma firetower lookout in the Flathead National Forest in Montana.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Seoul
item.description: Han Kang grew up in Seoul, a city that embraces “thousands of years of turbulence.” She recommends reading that draws from the various eras that have made up her hometown.
item.dc:creator: Han Kang

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A possible advance by Ukraine’s army.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen riding a tank near the village of Robotyne, in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region, last month.

item.title: Workers Use Excavator to Plow Through Great Wall of China
item.description: The pair, a 38-year-old man and 55-year-old woman, used an excavator to widen an existing gap and make a shortcut, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka, Yan Zhuang and Siyi Zhao
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Youyu County Public Security Bureau, via Reuters
item.media:description: Two workers were accused of causing “irreversible damage” to a section of the Great Wall of China, where they were accused of using an excavator to widen a gap, according to the Youyu County Public Security Bureau.

item.title: Ukraine Tries to Breach Russian Lines in Another Patch of Territory
item.description: Ukrainian soldiers are trying to build on a new breach in enemy lines, but the battle will not be easy, military analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Destruction near the village of Robotyne, in the Zaporizhzhia region of Ukraine, late last month.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine’s Next Move
item.description: Also, India’s G20 public relations blitz.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen riding a tank near the village of Robotyne, in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region, last month.

item.title: Graft in military spending becomes a headache for Ukraine.
item.description: The removal of Ukraine’s defense minister highlights the enduring challenge of corruption in Ukraine, which has emerged as a rare area of criticism of President Volodymyr Zelensky’s leadership.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian Army soldiers unloaded munitions from the back of a truck last week. Irregularities in procurement of weapons have been a persistent challenge for Ukraine.

item.title: Cuba Uncovers a Russian Human Trafficking Ring For the War in Ukraine
item.description: The Cuban government said it had begun criminal proceedings against a “trafficking network” that had been recruiting its citizens in both Russia and Cuba for Russia’s armed forces.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest blessing conscripted men at a recruiting office in Moscow in 2022. The Russian government has taken a number of measures to bolster its military ranks.

item.title: Biden Picks Jack Lew as Envoy to Israel During Time of Friction
item.description: Mr. Lew, a former Treasury secretary, would bring stature and a low-key style to the assignment of representing the president to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Jacob J. Lew served in the Obama and Clinton administrations before being nominated by President Biden to be the next ambassador to Israel.

item.title: Battlefield Update: The entrenchments Ukraine is encountering are ‘not as strong,’ an army spokesman says.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen riding a tank near the village of Robotyne, in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region, last month.

item.title: Hong Kong Must Have Framework to Recognize Same-Sex Unions, Court Rules
item.description: The ruling by the city’s Court of Final Appeal stops short of recognizing same-sex marriage, but some experts see the outcome as a small step forward.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Same-sex couples at an event to raise awareness of gay rights in Hong Kong in 2019, shortly after Taiwan’s government became the first in Asia to legalize same-sex marriage.

item.title: Northern Ireland Police Chief Simon Byrne Resigns Amid Mounting Scandals
item.description: A data breach and a court ruling have piled pressure on a police force that was founded on a promise to move past sectarian strife.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Liam McBurney/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Chief Constable Simon Byrne resigned from his position as head of Northern Ireland’s police force on Monday.

item.title: Earthquake sensors are helping document Russian bombings in new detail.
item.dc:creator: James Glanz and Josh Holder

item.title: This is how military service is sold on Russian TV.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Alina Lobzina, Sarah Kerr and Natalie Reneau

item.title: Can Kenya Bring Order to Haiti?
item.description: The African country has volunteered to send forces to Haiti as its security crisis spirals out of control. But the plan is facing pushback.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Andre Paultre and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Sheltering from gang violence at a sports arena in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

item.title: India Promotes the G20 Summit With Barnstorming Flair
item.description: With wall-to-wall promotion and a barnstorming flair, India’s governing party is milking the lead-up to this weekend’s summit for all it’s worth.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: India’s G20 logo features a lotus, also the symbol of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Planned talks between Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A photograph released by North Korean state news shows Kim Jong-un in July. Mr. Kim is expected to travel to meet President Vladimir V. Putin in Russia.

item.title: Sydney Suburb Is Shocked by Mass Destruction of Trees
item.description: The brazen culling of more than 250 trees at a waterside reserve in Australia, the speculation goes, had the goal of producing a better view.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Damaged trees in Castle Cove, Australia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Kamianka, Ukraine, Bears Legacy and Detritus of WWII and Putin’s War
item.description: The legacy of World War II lingers in the Ukrainian town of Kamianka, where tractors spit out shell casings, old and new. Now it has been destroyed by a new conflict.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nadiia Huk in front of what used to be her home in Kamianka, Ukraine. “Everything is broken,” she said.

item.title: Chinese Cars Star at Munich Auto Show, Underscoring German Economic Woes
item.description: China, an electric-vehicle juggernaut, will have at least seven brands on display, while Germany’s automakers are now a drag on their home economy.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.category: Guangzhou Xiaopeng Motors Technology Co Ltd (Xpeng Motors)
item.media:description: The I.A.A. Mobility, an auto show in Munich, arrives at a precarious time for the Germany auto industry, and the German economy generally.

item.title: As Saudis Consider Deal With Israel, Palestinians Seek Sway in Talks
item.description: The Palestinian leadership condemned efforts in 2020 to end Israel’s diplomatic isolation in the Arab world. Now, in the face of similar moves, they are trying a new tack.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Bandar Al-Jaloud/Saudi Royal Palace, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A picture provided by the Saudi Royal Palace of a meeting between the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Jeddah in April.

item.title: Putin Meets Erdogan to Discuss Grain Deal
item.description: Any notion that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey might be shifting away from his friendly ties with the Kremlin appeared to evaporate on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Sochi, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Kim and Putin Plan to Meet in Russia
item.description: Also, Xi Jinping might skip the Group of 20 summit.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: A photograph released by North Korean state news shows Kim Jong-un last month.

item.title: Sergei Surovikin, Russian General Detained After Wagner Mutiny, Is Released
item.description: Gen. Sergei Surovikin, who was seen as an ally of the mercenary leader Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, has re-emerged in public.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: In a photograph released by Russian state media, Gen. Sergei Surovikin, left, then commander of the Russian forces in Ukraine, with Defense Minister Sergei K. Shoigu, center, in December 2022.

item.title: Kim Jong-un and Putin Plan to Meet in Russia to Discuss Weapons
item.description: Russia seeks more weaponry for its war in Ukraine, and a North Korean delegation recently traveled to Russia by train to plan for Mr. Kim’s visit this month, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: A photograph released by North Korean state news shows Kim Jong-un, right, with Sergei K. Shoigu, the Russian defense minister, in July. Mr. Kim is expected to travel to meet President Vladimir V. Putin in Russia.

item.title: Have You Seen Paul McCartney’s Lost Bass Guitar? Tips Welcome.
item.description: For decades, mystery has surrounded the fate of the missing bass that accompanied the Beatles as they rocketed to fame. A new campaign is trying to find it.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The Beatles performing at the Cavern Club in Liverpool, England, in 1962.

item.title: When It Comes to China, Pope Francis Keeps Criticism in Check
item.description: Francis called relations with Beijing “very respectful,” though few clergy or Catholics from China went to see him during a visit to Mongolia, seemingly fearing reprisals.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving for Mass at the Steppe Arena in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, on Sunday, where two Hong Kong bishops joined him.

item.title: Urban Animals Can’t Take the Heat, Study Finds
item.description: A warming climate could make cities even less hospitable to wild mammals, according to new research.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Rishi Sunak Accused of Cutting U.K. School Rebuilding in Concrete Crisis
item.description: The prime minister was warned in his past job as finance chief, an official said, that hundreds of schools contained dangerously weak concrete. Now classrooms are having to shut.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Joe Giddens/Agence France-Presse Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak visiting new housing in Norwich, England. Blaming him for a failure to fix school buildings, he said, was “completely and utterly wrong.”

item.title: Xi Jinping of China Looks Set to Skip G20 in Snub to India
item.description: Xi Jinping has never missed the annual Group of 20 gathering since taking power in 2012. Beijing would not explain his apparent decision to forgo the event in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, center, meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at the BRICS Summit in Johannesburg last month.

item.title: Graft in Ukraine Military Spending Becomes a Headache
item.description: The removal of the defense minister highlights the enduring challenge of corruption in Ukraine, which has emerged as a rare area of criticism of President Volodymyr Zelensky’s leadership.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian Army soldiers unload munitions from the back of a truck last week. Irregularities in procurement of weapons have been a persistent challenge for Ukraine.

item.title: Perilous, Icy Mission Rescues Sick Worker in Antarctica
item.description: It took an icebreaker ship and two long-range helicopters to evacuate the staff member from an Australian research base to advanced medical care.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Ukraine Arrests Oligarch Ihor Kolomoisky Amid Corruption Inquiry
item.description: The detention of Ihor Kolomoisky came as Ukraine steps up efforts to punish graft and make its case for closer integration with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The Ukrainian billionaire Ihor Kolomoisky, center, attended a court hearing in Kyiv on Saturday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak’s Conservative Party Embraces Divisive Issues in U.K.
item.description: Climate. Refugees. Crime. With an election looming next year, the prime minister and his party are turning to populist issues.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain, right, has denounced stabbings in London, which has an opposition mayor, and promised tighter regulation of knives.

item.title: Facing Threats, U.S. Navy Struggles to Modernize Its Ships
item.description: A new generation of cheaper and more flexible vessels could be vital in any conflict with China, but the Navy remains lashed to big shipbuilding programs driven by tradition, political influence and jobs.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 800-acre Huntington Ingalls complex in Pascagoula, Miss., is one of seven major Navy shipbuilding yards across the country.

item.title: Back to New Jersey, Where the Universe Began
item.description: A half-century ago, a radio telescope in Holmdel, N.J., sent two astronomers 13.8 billion years back in time — and opened a cosmic window that scientists have been peering through ever since.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye and Hiroko Masuike
item.media:description: The Holmdel Horn Antenna in Monmouth County, N.J., with its caretaker, Dr. Robert Wilson, a senior scientist at the Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Who Is Rustem Umerov, Zelensky’s Nominee for Ukraine’s Defense Minister?
item.description: Though a member of an opposition political party, Mr. Umerov has taken on several critical roles for the Zelensky government since the Russian invasion last year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Dogukan Keskinkilic/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rustem Umerov in Kyiv in May 2022. He has been clear that he is aligned with Ukraine’s president on refusing to cede any territory to Russia.

item.title: Music Videos Promote Niger’s Military After a Coup
item.description: Music videos praising the military have proliferated since generals seized power, highlighting the army’s longstanding importance in Niger and popular dissatisfaction with civilian rule.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Sarah Kerr
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Johan Floderus, E.U. Official From Sweden, Is Imprisoned in Iran
item.description: The case of Johan Floderus, kept under wraps for more than a year, has become part of Iran’s “hostage diplomacy” as Tehran seeks concessions from the West.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Changes in Ukraine’s military leadership.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukraine’s defense minister, Oleksii Reznikov, in April.

item.title: In Spain, Illegal Pot Farms Are Being Blamed for Blackouts
item.description: Spain’s largest electricity company says daily power outages are caused by illegal indoor marijuana farms that overload the grid. “Easy excuse,” residents reply.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers installing new electrical cables in northern Granada, Spain.

item.title: Monday Briefing: China’s Mobilization Against Espionage
item.description: Also, India’s first solar mission.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Surveillance cameras in Shanghai in March.

item.title: Zelensky Says He’ll Replace Oleksii Reznikov as Ukraine’s Defense Minister
item.description: The fate of the defense minister, Oleksii Reznikov, had been the subject of increasing speculation in Ukraine. It was the biggest shake-up in Ukraine’s government since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukraine’s defense minister, Oleksii Reznikov, in April.

item.title: South African Inquiry Rebuts U.S. Charge on Russian Arms
item.description: A government investigation about a Russian ship contradicts U.S. accusations that South Africa provided arms to fight Ukraine, President Cyril Ramaphosa said. But a government report won’t be released, he added.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The Lady R cargo ship docked in December at Simon’s Town Naval Base in South Africa.

item.title: Netanyahu Calls for Deportations of Immigrants After Clashes in Tel Aviv
item.description: The Israeli prime minister’s remarks revived a debate about the fate of thousands of asylum seekers after hundreds of opposing Eritrean groups faced off in Tel Aviv this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Rival groups of Eritreans threw stones at each other and police officers in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: Parisian Pools, Up Close and Personal
item.description: Swimming in Paris is a full-on cultural experience, offering intimate views into the French psyche, which is on near-naked display in the swimming lanes, locker rooms and (mostly coed) showers.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: People swimming beneath the vaulted ceiling of the Butte-aux-Cailles municipal pool last month in Paris.
